paper_title: The Relative Power of Employment-to-Employment Reallocation and Unemployment Exits in Predicting Wage Growth

claim_object.outcome_concept: Composition-adjusted wage growth (change in log nominal earnings) at the market level
claim_object.treatment_concept: Composition-adjusted EE (employment-to-employment) transition rate at the market level
claim_object.estimand_concept: Within-market predictive association between EE reallocation rate and wage growth, conditional on other labor market flows and time trend
claim_object.target_population: Demographic labor markets (sex x race x agegroup x education cells) observed monthly in SIPP panels 1996-2013, employed-to-employed eligible workers

baseline_specs.label: Table1-Spec1-NomEarn
baseline_specs.notes: Bivariate second stage: EE only + year_month + market FE

baseline_specs.label: Table1-Spec5-NomEarn
baseline_specs.notes: EE + UE + UR + year_month + market FE

baseline_specs.label: Table1-Spec6-NomEarn
baseline_specs.notes: All flows + year_month + market FE (fullest second-stage spec)

two_stage_procedure.description: First stage: individual-level areg absorbing market*time FE to extract composition-adjusted market-level transition rates and wage growth. Second stage: market-level areg of predicted wage growth FE on predicted transition rate FEs, absorbing market FE with year_month as continuous control.

first_stage.e_controls_notes: lag(depvar) is also included for EE and wage first-stage regressions only, not for EU/EN. See do-file lines 165 and 197.

dependent_variables.ee: eetrans_i (EE transition indicator; uses e_controls + lag(depvar))
dependent_variables.ue: uetrans_i (UE transition indicator; uses u_controls only)
dependent_variables.ne: netrans_i (NE transition indicator; uses u_controls only)
dependent_variables.eu: eutrans_i (EU transition indicator; uses e_controls only, no lag(depvar))
dependent_variables.en: entrans_i (EN transition indicator; uses e_controls only, no lag(depvar))
dependent_variables.dw: d{depvar} (change in log wage/earnings; uses e_controls + eetrans_i)

first_stage.notes: The FE predicted from first stage are averaged within mkt_t cells and used as generated regressors in second stage. Note: lag(depvar) enters only the EE and wage growth first-stage regressions, not the EU/EN regressions.

two_stage_procedure.linkage_notes: First-stage controls are fixed by the paper's procedure and not varied in the second stage. The first-stage FE extraction uses the same control set for all employed-eligible regressions (e_controls) and all unemployed-eligible regressions (u_controls). Second-stage regressors are the predicted FE from first stage, so varying first-stage controls would change the generated regressors. We treat first-stage controls as linked/fixed and vary specification choices at the second-stage level.
two_stage_procedure.g3_g4_eligibility_notes: For hourly wage outcomes (G3/G4), the do-file modifies EZeligible and DWeligible by additionally requiring lagphr==1 (paid hourly). This means the first stage for G3/G4 runs on a different subsample than G1/G2. The first-stage FE extraction must be re-run for G3/G4, not shared with G1/G2.

constraints.controls_count_notes: Second-stage flow regressors range from 1 (EE only) to 6 (all flows: EE+UE+UR+NE+EN+EU). Spec 7 has 4 (grouped), Spec 9 has 7 (all flows + EE interaction) but Spec 9 changes the estimand (see reclassification). The year_month_num continuous control is always present and not counted.
constraints.linked_adjustment_notes: First-stage and second-stage are linked: changing first-stage controls would change the generated regressors in the second stage. We hold first-stage controls fixed and vary second-stage composition of flow regressors.
constraints.max_fe_dimensions_notes: Baseline uses market FE (absorbed) in second stage. Adding time FE (year_month dummies instead of continuous control) is feasible.

rc/controls/sets (second-stage flow comp.description: Vary which labor market flow FEs enter the second-stage regression alongside xee. These are the paper's revealed second-stage specifications that preserve the EE claim.
rc/controls/sets (second-stage flow comp.notes: 5 specs that include xee and vary which other flows are conditioned on. Specs 1, 4, 5, 6, 7 from Table 1. Specs 2 and 3 (UE-only, UR-only) are excluded because they drop xee entirely and therefore do not estimate the EE-wage claim. They are reclassified as explore/treatment/ue_only and explore/treatment/ur_only. Spec 8 (job stayers) is reclassified as rc/sample. Spec 9 (EE interaction) is reclassified as explore/ because the interaction changes the focal estimand.

rc/controls/first_stage.description: Vary first-stage individual-level control sets used to extract composition-adjusted FE. This changes the generated regressors.
rc/controls/first_stage.notes: The paper uses e_controls = {lagstate, laguni, lagsiz, lagocc, lagind, lagpub} + lag(depvar) for EE and wage regressions, and u_controls = {lagstate} for UE/NE/UR regressions. Minimal: drop some e_controls. Extended: add u_controls variables to e_controls or vice versa. No_lag_depvar: exclude the lagged dependent variable from first-stage EE and wage regressions. Add_lag_hours: add lagged log(hours).

rc/sample.notes: The data spans SIPP panels 1996-2013. Pre-crisis = before 2008, post-crisis = 2008+. Drop short spells: require individuals observed >= 3 months. Job stayers: restrict second-stage sample to eetrans_i==0 & lagemp>0 (originally Spec 8 in Table 1, reclassified from rc/controls because it is a sample restriction, not a controls change).

rc/fe.description: Vary the second-stage fixed effects and time control.
rc/fe.notes: Baseline uses market FE (absorbed) + year_month as continuous control. Replace: use year_month dummies instead of continuous control. Quadratic: use year_month + year_month^2. Note: rc/fe/drop/market_fe has been reclassified to explore/identification/pooled because dropping market FE changes the identifying variation from within-market to pooled, which is a fundamental change.

rc/weights.notes: Baseline uses SIPP person weights (wgt). Unweighted: no weights. Trim: cap extreme weights at 99th percentile.

rc/data/aggregation.description: Vary how demographic markets are defined, which changes the mkt and mkt_t groupings.
rc/data/aggregation.notes: Baseline: mkt = sex x race x agegroup x education (2x2x5x5 = 100 groups). Coarser: drop race (2x5x5 = 50). Note: finer_markets (adding state) has been moved to explore/data/aggregation/finer_markets because it requires re-running the full first-stage on ~5,000+ market groups with very thin cells, is computationally speculative, and the paper never considers geographic disaggregation.

core_universe.infer_notes: Baseline uses Stata areg default SE (HC1 at the individual level, which is conventional OLS SE after FE absorption). Clustering at market level (100 clusters) is natural given the market-level generated regressors. Clustering at the time level is relevant for potential serial correlation. Two-way clustering market x time would address both.

explore_spec_ids.description: UE-only second-stage regression (Table 1 Spec 2). Drops xee. Tests the UE-wage relationship as an alternative treatment concept.
UR-only second-stage regression (Table 1 Spec 3). Drops xee. Tests the UR-wage relationship as an alternative treatment concept.
All flows + EE interaction (Table 1 Spec 9). xee_i = xee * eetrans_i changes the focal estimand: the coefficient on xee now represents the EE effect for non-movers only.
Drop market FE from second stage (originally rc/fe/drop/market_fe). Changes from within-market to pooled identification.
Add state to market definition (~5,000 groups). Computationally speculative and not revealed by the paper.

breakdown.notes: Core battery: 5 (baseline flow specs: EE-only, EE+UE, EE+UE+UR, all flows, grouped flows) + 5 (first-stage control variants) x 3 (anchor specs: Spec1, Spec5, Spec6) = 15 + 6 (sample variants) x 3 (anchor specs) = 18 + 2 (FE variants) x 3 = 6 + 2 (weight variants) x 3 = 6 + 1 (market def variant) x 3 = 3 + 4 (inference variants) x 3 = 12 + ~15 high-value cross-axis combos. Total: 5 + 15 + 18 + 6 + 6 + 3 + 12 + 15 = 80. Budget of 100 gives headroom for additional combos.

sampling.notes: Full enumeration is feasible for all axes. No random sampling needed. The second-stage flow composition is already fully enumerated by the paper. Other axes are small (1-6 variants each). One-axis-at-a-time from 3 anchor specs (Spec1=EE only, Spec5=EE+UE+UR, Spec6=all flows) keeps the total manageable.

diagnostics_plan.notes: The two-stage procedure uses generated regressors, which means second-stage SE are inconsistent unless corrected (Murphy-Topel / bootstrap). The paper does not address this. Diagnosing the SE correction is important.
Test for serial correlation in second-stage residuals given the panel structure of markets over time.

claim_object.outcome_concept: Composition-adjusted wage growth (change in log real earnings) at the market level
claim_object.treatment_concept: Composition-adjusted EE transition rate at the market level
claim_object.estimand_concept: Within-market predictive association between EE reallocation rate and wage growth (real), conditional on other labor market flows and time trend
claim_object.target_population: Same as G1 (demographic labor markets in SIPP 1996-2013)

constraints.notes: Same two-stage procedure as G1, with real earnings as the outcome. Shares the same first-stage extraction procedure (same eligibility as G1).

core_universe.notes: Same structure as G1. The specification surface is identical except the outcome variable is real earnings (logern) instead of nominal earnings (logern_nom). All RC axes, FE, sample, weight, inference variants apply identically. First-stage extraction is shared with G1 (same eligibility criteria).

sampling.notes: Full enumeration feasible. Same as G1.

claim_object.outcome_concept: Composition-adjusted wage growth (change in log nominal hourly wage) at the market level
claim_object.treatment_concept: Composition-adjusted EE transition rate at the market level
claim_object.estimand_concept: Within-market predictive association between EE reallocation rate and hourly wage growth, conditional on other labor market flows and time trend
claim_object.target_population: Demographic labor markets in SIPP 1996-2013, restricted to paid-hourly workers (lagphr==1)

baseline_specs.label: Table1-Spec6-NomHrWage
baseline_specs.notes: EE coefficient becomes small and insignificant (p=0.104) when all flows are included. This is a key finding: the EE-wage relationship operates through earnings, not hourly wages.

constraints.notes: Same structure as G1 but with smaller sample (paid-hourly workers only, ~3.2M obs). IMPORTANT: first-stage eligibility differs from G1/G2. EZeligible and DWeligible additionally require lagphr==1. First-stage FE must be re-extracted on this restricted sample.

core_universe.notes: Same RC axis structure as G1. Outcome is nominal hourly wage. Sample restricted to lagphr==1 in first stage. First-stage extraction must be re-run (NOT shared with G1/G2).

sampling.notes: Full enumeration feasible. Same as G1.

claim_object.outcome_concept: Composition-adjusted wage growth (change in log real hourly wage) at the market level
claim_object.treatment_concept: Composition-adjusted EE transition rate at the market level
claim_object.estimand_concept: Within-market predictive association between EE reallocation rate and real hourly wage growth, conditional on other labor market flows and time trend
claim_object.target_population: Demographic labor markets in SIPP 1996-2013, restricted to paid-hourly workers

baseline_specs.label: Table1-Spec6-RealHrWage
baseline_specs.notes: EE coefficient becomes NEGATIVE and significant when all flows are included. This is a key finding: EE reallocation does not predict real hourly wage growth once other flows are controlled for.

constraints.notes: Same as G3. First-stage eligibility additionally requires lagphr==1.

core_universe.notes: Same structure as G1. Outcome is real hourly wage. First-stage extraction must be re-run (NOT shared with G1/G2).

sampling.notes: Full enumeration feasible. Same as G1.

shared_rc_axes.description: All four baseline groups share the same RC axes since they differ only in outcome variable (and eligibility sample for G3/G4). The following RC specifications apply to each baseline group.

second_stage_flow_specs.description: 5 core second-stage flow compositions from Table 1 that preserve the EE claim

reclassified_specs.label: Spec 2: UE only (drops xee; alternative treatment concept)
Spec 3: UR only (drops xee; alternative treatment concept)
Spec 8: All flows, job stayers (reclassified as sample restriction)
Spec 9: All flows + EE interaction (changes focal estimand)

first_stage_control_variants.description: Vary the individual-level controls used in the first-stage FE extraction. This changes the generated regressors used in the second stage.

specs.notes: Drop occupation, industry, union, firm size, public sector from employed controls. Match to unemployed controls.
Use full employed controls for unemployed regressions too (where variable exists / is non-missing).
Add laguni to the unemployed controls. Intermediate between baseline and fully extended.
Drop lag(depvar) from the EE first-stage regression and eetrans_i from the wage growth first-stage regression. The lagged dependent variable may introduce bias.
Add lagged hours (log(hrs) lagged) to employed controls as additional labor supply control.

sample_variants.description: Drop the 1996 SIPP panel (earliest panel, potentially different measurement)
Drop the 2008 SIPP panel (latest panel, partial coverage)
Drop individuals with fewer than 3 consecutive monthly observations
Restrict second-stage sample to job stayers (eetrans_i==0 & lagemp>0). Originally Spec 8 in Table 1. Reclassified from rc/controls because it is a sample restriction, not a controls change.

fe_variants.description: Replace year_month continuous control with year_month fixed effects (dummies) in second stage
Use quadratic time trend (year_month + year_month^2) instead of linear

weight_variants.description: Trim SIPP person weights at 99th percentile

market_definition_variants.description: Coarser market definition: sex x agegroup x education (drop race). Reduces from 100 to 50 market cells.

inference_variants.description: Cluster SE at market level (100 clusters). Natural given market-level generated regressors.
Cluster SE at year_month level (~176 clusters). Addresses serial correlation.
Two-way clustering: market x year_month. Addresses both cross-sectional and serial dependence.
inference_variants.notes: Two-way clustering with 100 market clusters and ~176 time clusters.

cross_axis_specs.description: A small number of high-value two-axis combinations
examples: first_stage_no_lag_depvar x all 5 core flow specs (test generated regressor sensitivity)
cluster_market x all 5 core flow specs (inference robustness across flow specs)
unweighted x all 5 core flow specs (weight sensitivity across flow specs)

execution_plan.total_across_groups: 4 groups x ~95 specs = ~380 total specs (but G1/G2 share first-stage extraction, and G3/G4 share first-stage extraction)
